titleInfo.title: Enigmatic, Abundant and Active Anaerolineae Mediate Carbon Transformations in a Salt Marsh Ecosystem

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Coastal salt marshes are some of the most productive ecosystems on Earth, with over half of plant biomass production occurring in the belowground. In this belowground environment, particularly the rhizosphere, Anaerolineae (Phylum Chloroflexota) has been reported as one of the most abundant microbial groups. To date, analyses of Anaerolineae have provided evidence for an anaerobic fermentative metabolism and an ability to utilize diverse carbon sources including cellulose. However, this class remains poorly understood, particularly in a salt marsh context, despite their high abundances in this environment. Here, 55 medium- and high-quality Anaerolineae metagenome assembled genomes (MAGs) were generated from salt marsh rhizosphere samples. These Anaerolineae were primarily classified as members of the Anaerolineales and Promineofilales orders. Metabolic functional traits and gene expression were determined by mapping metagenome and metatranscriptome reads to MAGs. Nearly all Anaerolineae encoded and transcribed genes required for oxidation of both simple sugars and more complex carbon compounds including cellulose, fermentation, and for carbon fixation. A large portion of MAGs also encoded genes for both aerobic and anaerobic metabolism suggesting metabolic flexibility regarding respiration. Further, the majority of Anaerolineae transcribed genes necessary to produce potentially biomedically important secondary metabolites such as non-ribosomal peptide synthases (NRPS) and polyketide synthases (PKS). The data revealed that the belowground salt marsh Anaerolineae in the rhizosphere are important players in carbon cycling, including degradation of simple carbon compounds to more recalcitrant plant material, such as cellulose, using a diversity of electron acceptors and represent an unexplored reservoir of novel secondary metabolites. These new insights reveal a central role of Anaerolineae in salt marsh biogeochemistry.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Olivia Mason, Professor Directing Thesis; Michael Stukel, Committee Member; Robert Spencer, Committee Member.
